text:
This is an old post, but we're still experiencing unexpected behavior.
{{ name }} behaves differently depending if you are manually 'dragging and dropping' it onto a page VS declaring/creating it in a template.

If we have a template where we have defined a module that has a div with an id made with {{name}} it gets the id "dnd_area-module-2". If we drag and drop the same module into the page it will get an id like "widget_1676970114818". The latter is dynamic, the first is ~static~. This utterly breaks any dynamic (js) approach we have for that module when the module is made via a template. Edit: Main issue is that the one generated via template is using "-", which js really disslikes!
and it will show the non cached version
When you update the page though HubSpot automatically expires that cache
Probably an issue with setting default. If you toggle it off and one does it work?
Does anyone have experience adding telephone numbers to a module? It seems that when you add tel: to a link it does not work

<@U04BGQL6AGY> Yeah this happened to use too. We just refactored our js to work in the module.js file and used data attributes to control the dynamic parts.

What does you JS look like? You can probably move it to the js file

Currently, there aren’t any ways to place constraints on the way modules are placed and sized within a `dnd_area`. It’s either down to trusting your editors with the power to make things ugly, or trying to make the layout so flexible that they can’t possibly ruin it.

Is there any way to make HubDB row field as optional in modules? Why because is.. it has to hold the TableID value as mandatory and it is affecting in pushing of modules between sandbox and production account.
